Unique identifier for the current configuration.

detaileddescription.para: The configuration ID is derived from the IOV of the currently loaded conditions. The LHC fill number could also be a good number in the future, but I'm not sure how to extract that at the moment.

memberdef.argsstring: (const coral::Blob &ints, const std::vector< bool > &mask, bool state) const
memberdef.name: decodeIntV0

briefdescription.para: Function used in decoding the beam intensities.

detaileddescription.para: This function can decode the beam intensity blob in case it was encoded with "storage mode 0".
In this mode the blob only holds the information about the filled bunches, as they are defined in the FILLPARAMS folder.

parameterdescription.para: The blob holding the beam intensities
A mask specifying which intensities to extract
The flag state to select from the specified mask

briefdescription.para: Function used in decoding the beam intensities.

detaileddescription.para: This function can decode the beam intensity blob in case it was encoded with "storage mode 1".
In this mode the blob holds the intensities of all the 3564 possible bunches. The code has to select the intensities of the bunches that we're interested in.

parameterdescription.para: The blob holding the beam intensities
The BCIDs for which the intensities have to be extracted

briefdescription.para: Function used in decoding the beam intensities.

detaileddescription.para: This function can decode the beam intensity blob in case it was encoded with "storage mode 2".
In this mode the blob specifies exactly which BCIDs it holds information about.

parameterdescription.para: The blob holding the beam intensities
The BCIDs for which the intensities have to be extracted

briefdescription.para: Implementation reading the information from the LHC conditions DB.

detaileddescription.para: This implementation of the tool behaves pretty much like TrigConfBunchCrossingTool. But instead of reading the BCIDs of the colliding bunches out of the trigger configuration, it reads them from the LHC conditions, stored in the TDAQ COOL folders.
Apparently for some runs this information is more reliable than the trigger configuration.
It also acts as a bunch crossing configuration provider, implementing the Trig::IBunchCrossingConfProvider interface.
